learnings.title: Meeting Types, Goals, and Alternatives
learnings.bodyMd:
# Meeting Types, Goals, and Alternatives

## Overview
Use meetings selectively. Choose the right type (decision, alignment, brainstorm, 1:1) or an async alternative.

## Key Concepts
- Goal clarity and pre‑reads.
- Agenda with timeboxes and roles.
- Async alternatives: docs, Looms, polls.

## Examples
- Convert status meetings into async updates.
- Keep decision meetings small and prepared.

## Common Pitfalls
- Meetings without a defined outcome.
- Inviting spectators who don’t contribute.

## Summary
Meet only when necessary, with clear goals and the right people. Default to async updates for information sharing.

learnings.title: Facilitation and Inclusive Participation
learnings.bodyMd:
# Facilitation and Inclusive Participation

## Overview
Strong facilitation balances voices, keeps time, and surfaces dissent safely across cultures and seniority.

## Key Concepts
- Round‑robins and hand‑raises.
- Parking lot for off‑topic items.
- Capturing dissent and next steps.

## Examples
- Call on quiet participants by name.
- Summarize: "We have two unresolved risks—owners A and B."

## Common Pitfalls
- Allowing dominance by a few voices.
- No capture of decisions and risks.

## Summary
Facilitate actively: balance airtime, protect agenda, and record outcomes and open items visibly.

learnings.title: Cross‑Time‑Zone Collaboration
learnings.bodyMd:
# Cross‑Time‑Zone Collaboration

## Overview
Design collaboration so progress continues across time zones with minimal friction.

## Key Concepts
- Core hours and handoff windows.
- Handover notes and checklists.
- Tooling for async collaboration.

## Examples
- Daily handoff doc with status and blockers.
- Shared kanban with explicit WIP and owners.

## Common Pitfalls
- Blockers waiting 24 hours due to unclear ownership.
- Meetings scheduled in someone’s midnight.

## Summary
Create structured handoffs and shared boards. Rotate inconvenient times and clarify ownership to keep work moving.

learnings.title: Decision Frameworks (RACI/DACI)
learnings.bodyMd:
# Decision Frameworks (RACI/DACI)

## Overview
Clarify who decides, who is accountable, and who must be consulted or informed.

## Key Concepts
- RACI: Responsible, Accountable, Consulted, Informed.
- DACI: Driver, Approver, Contributors, Informed.
- Single‑threaded ownership.

## Examples
- DACI for a vendor selection decision.
- RACI for a cross‑team launch.

## Common Pitfalls
- Shared accountability leading to diffusion.
- Unclear approver causing stalls.

## Summary
Assign roles explicitly for each decision. Keep approver singular and visible to accelerate throughput.

learnings.title: Notes, Recordings, and Follow‑Ups
learnings.bodyMd:
# Notes, Recordings, and Follow‑Ups

## Overview
Capture outcomes and action items immediately so momentum isn’t lost and context persists.

## Key Concepts
- Notes template: decisions, actions, risks.
- Recording and transcripts where appropriate.
- Distribution within 24 hours.

## Examples
- Shared notes doc with owners and due dates.
- Link notes in the calendar invite post‑meeting.

## Common Pitfalls
- No notes leading to re‑litigation.
- Hidden notes not shared with stakeholders.

## Summary
Write short, structured notes with clear owners and dates. Share promptly and file where they’re easily found later.
